Justification: The decision stunned OpenAI’s employees and exposed board members to tough questions about their qualifications to manage such a high-profile company.

Title: Chief Executive

SourcedStatement: Mr. Sutskever and others critical of Mr. Altman were jettisoned from the board, whose members now include Bret Taylor, an early Facebook officer and former co-chief executive of Salesforce, and Larry Summers, the former Treasury Department secretary. The only holdover is Adam D’Angelo, chief executive of the question-and-answer site, Quora.

Title: null
Justification: The OpenAI debacle has illustrated how building A.I. systems is testing whether businesspeople who want to make money from artificial intelligence can work in sync with researchers who worry that what they are building could eventually eliminate jobs or become a threat if technologies like autonomous weapons grow out of control.

SourcedStatement: Among the tensions leading up to Mr. Altman’s ouster and quick return involved his conflict with Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology.
Name: Helen Toner
Title: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Justification: Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology.

SourcedStatement: A few weeks before Mr. Altman’s firing, he met with Ms. Toner to discuss a paper she had co-written for the Georgetown center.
Name: Sam Altman
Title: Chief Executive
Justification: Mr. Altman met with Ms. Toner to discuss a paper she had co-written for the Georgetown center.

SourcedStatement: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.
Name: Sam Altman
Title: Chief Executive
Justification: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.

SourcedStatement: In the email, Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.
Name: Sam Altman
Title: Chief Executive
Justification: Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.

SourcedStatement: Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.
Name: Helen Toner
Title: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Justification: Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.

SourcedStatement: But Mr. Altman disagreed.
Name: Sam Altman
Title: Chief Executive
Justification: Mr. Altman disagreed.

SourcedStatement: “I did not feel we’re on the same page on the damage of all this,” he wrote in the email. “Any amount of criticism from a board member carries a lot of weight.”
Name: Sam Altman
Title: Chief Executive
Justification: Mr. Altman wrote in the email.
